docs.snippet: Donna Reed, the Academy Award-winning actress who starred in more than 40 movies and portrayed the quintessential mother and wife of middle America on television's ''Donna Reed Show'' in the 1950's and 60's, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Donna Reed, the Academy Award-winning actress who starred in more than 40 movies and portrayed the quintessential mother and wife of middle America on television's ''Donna Reed Show'' in the 1950's and 60's, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 64 years old. Miss Reed had entered Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in December for treatment of a bleeding ulcer. The malignancy was discovered during tests for the ulcer condition.

headline.main: DONNA REED, OSCAR WINNER AND TV STAR, IS DEAD AT 64

docs.snippet: For fashion designers on Seventh Avenue, the fall collection has the longest lead time of the year. Spring clothes are introduced in November, after which designers frequently take long holiday vacations to rest and get the creative juices flowing...
docs.lead_paragraph: For fashion designers on Seventh Avenue, the fall collection has the longest lead time of the year. Spring clothes are introduced in November, after which designers frequently take long holiday vacations to rest and get the creative juices flowing. They arrive back in their studios in January with almost four months to develop the fall styles that will be presented at the end of April and the first of May. This allows time to ponder the overall direction in which fashion is flowing as well as to determine the designer's part in the development. Even Oscar de la Renta, one of the few designers in the top price bracket who does a separate summer line, is immersed in fall planning.

headline.main: FOUR DESIGNERS PREDICT THE SHAPE OF FALL TO COME

docs.snippet: JANUARY is rather a schizophrenic time in the fashion world.   Shoppers are combing the clearance racks of stores for bargains on leftover winter clothes. Stores are starting to bring in spring merchandise. And designers are showing their summer c...
docs.lead_paragraph: JANUARY is rather a schizophrenic time in the fashion world. Shoppers are combing the clearance racks of stores for bargains on leftover winter clothes. Stores are starting to bring in spring merchandise. And designers are showing their summer collections - except for those who are already showing fall clothes. Harve Benard's winter coats and suits will be modeled today, but mainly it's men's wear for fall that is being shown now. And it's Bill Robinson's first collection on his own that people have been talking about.

docs.snippet: Before he even takes the oath of office on Tuesday, Guatemala's new civilian leader is facing angry demands.   On Friday, nearly 1,000 relatives of missing people marched through the capital demanding to know the fate of their loved ones. At the r...
docs.lead_paragraph: Before he even takes the oath of office on Tuesday, Guatemala's new civilian leader is facing angry demands. On Friday, nearly 1,000 relatives of missing people marched through the capital demanding to know the fate of their loved ones. At the rear of the march was a contingent of dissatisfied teachers, who are threatening to call a nationwide strike if the new government does not move quickly to meet their wage demands. President-elect Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, who is to take office on Tuesday, reiterated last week that he would not order an investigation into the whereabouts of missing people. Such an inquiry, diplomats and political activists say, would probably anger the army and could provoke a coup.

headline.main: GUATEMALA'S NEXT LEADER ALREADY FACES DEMANDS

byline.original: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi has warned Parliament that instability in the Middle East has created a ''high risk'' that Italy will face new terrorist attacks.   In his semiannual report to Parliament on the activities of Italian intelligence servi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi has warned Parliament that instability in the Middle East has created a ''high risk'' that Italy will face new terrorist attacks. In his semiannual report to Parliament on the activities of Italian intelligence services, Mr. Craxi said Italy had uncovered about 70 foreign spies in the last six months, more than usual. He did not reveal their nationalities but said the large number suggested Italy was facing an unusual period of violence. The Prime Minister, leader of the Socialist Party, said the country faced a ''permanent danger posed by certain Middle East groups whose terrorist initiatives can be seen in the wider context of international subversion.''

headline.main: ITALIAN CHIEF WARNS OF HIGH RISK OF MORE ATTACKS

byline.original: By E. J. DIONNE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Midway through Martin Ritt's new film, ''Murphy's Romance,'' starring Sally Field and James Garner, the latter explains to Miss Field's young son that all the blood and gore in a slasher film they've just seen is phony.   ''They fake everything ou...
docs.lead_paragraph: Midway through Martin Ritt's new film, ''Murphy's Romance,'' starring Sally Field and James Garner, the latter explains to Miss Field's young son that all the blood and gore in a slasher film they've just seen is phony. ''They fake everything out there in Hollywood,'' Mr. Garner observes knowingly in the film, opening Friday in New York at the Bay Cinema, Baronet and the New Carnegie. The jab has a sly irony, coming in a movie made by Mr. Ritt. The 71-year-old director - who started in show business 50 years ago in New York as an Off Broadway actor - has built a widely admired, if seldom honored, film career by making pictures long on character, depth and social commitment, qualities that are tough to fake. Since 1956, in two dozen films as diverse as ''Norma Rae,'' ''Cross Creek,'' ''Sounder,'' ''Conrack,'' ''Hombre,'' ''Hud,'' ''The Spy Who Came in From the Cold'' and ''The Long Hot Summer,'' Mr. Ritt has specialized in unflashy, quietly moving studies of human relationships and moral choice.

headline.main: MARTIN RITT: HUAN RELATIONSHIPS AND MORAL CHOCES FUEL HIS MOVIES

byline.original: By THOMAS O'CONNOR; Thomas O'Connor covers arts and entertainment for The Orange County (Calif.) Register

docs.snippet: If the Philippines had an official national dish, it would probably be a sort of stew known as adobo. Adobo is actually a process by which anything - fish, fowl, vegetables or meat - is marinated for five hours or more in vinegar, soy sauce and sp...
docs.lead_paragraph: If the Philippines had an official national dish, it would probably be a sort of stew known as adobo. Adobo is actually a process by which anything - fish, fowl, vegetables or meat - is marinated for five hours or more in vinegar, soy sauce and spices, then cooked in hot oil, garnished with an egg and served with boiled rice. Most Filipinos know it as a durable and distinctive meal of either chicken or pork or a combination of the two. Adobo is the first thing most Filipinos who have been abroad request when they come home, says Oscar (Chito) Silerio, an executive chef at the Manila Hotel. For visitors to the Philippines and at the growing number of Filipino restaurants in the United States, like San Francisco's Tito Reyes, it is a fine introduction to the island nation's varied cuisine.

headline.main: ADOBO: SPICY STEW OF THE PHILIPPINES

byline.original: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO is a freelance journalist who lived in the Far East for four years and is now based in London

docs.snippet: Michael Feinstein, the 29-year-old singer and pianist who has spent years cataloguing the work of Ira Gershwin, Harry Warren and Oscar Levant, is an avid student of American show music. But the Los Angeles-based musician, who opened an extended en...
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Feinstein, the 29-year-old singer and pianist who has spent years cataloguing the work of Ira Gershwin, Harry Warren and Oscar Levant, is an avid student of American show music. But the Los Angeles-based musician, who opened an extended engagement at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) on Tuesday, is also a natural entertainer whose curatorial experience supplies his act with a wealth of humorous show-business lore that he skillfully incorporates as running patter.

headline.main: CAGBARET: MICHAEL FEINSTEIN AT THE ALGONQUIN

docs.snippet: Guatemala's President-elect said today that he would convene a meeting of Central American Presidents here next week.   The meeting, which would be the first of its kind since the leftist Sandinista Front took power in Nicaragua six years ago, is ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Guatemala's President-elect said today that he would convene a meeting of Central American Presidents here next week. The meeting, which would be the first of its kind since the leftist Sandinista Front took power in Nicaragua six years ago, is scheduled for Wednesday, the day after Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo is to assume the Guatemalan presidency. The Central American leaders are among foreign dignitaries expected to attend the inauguration. Mr. Cerezo and his associates have indirectly criticized United States policy in the region for what they say is its excessive reliance on force. No United States representatives are to take part in the meeting Wednesday.

byline.original: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to the New York Times
